messages.messageBody:
Milt wrote:

> ... I do say my hawk paintings are quite outstanding,
> 50 + now, not too shabby.90+ % edo period,
> Soga school, Kano school, Tosa school, I love them.

Ah well, if you ever fall on hard times you can hawk the paintings and keep the
tsuba...

Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: Re: Chicago
messages.msgSnippet: ... comply. We have the Art Institute if you are interested in Asian ceramics, Japanese ukiyo-e. The Field Museum has a large holding of tsuba but they do not
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Matthew E. Hoyle"
<matthewhoyle@w...> wrote:
> Ask "the infamous" Milt, he should know, since he lives in Chicago.
>
> Sujikabuto@a...
>
> Matt
>
>
>since my name is specifically targeted , I have no choice but to
comply.
We have the Art Institute if you are interested in Asian ceramics,
Japanese ukiyo-e.

The Field Museum has a large holding of tsuba but they do not display
them publicly.
We local yokels have a respected old timer that can arrange private
viewing . No, not me, I am not that respectable.
Other than that, there are a few collectors scattered allover the
landscape that may be willing to show you their stuffs but they have
to know you well first, I reckon. Personally. my sword collection is
low to mid range , no juyo. A lot of rusty tsuba I am working on but
I do say my hawk paintings are quite outstanding, 50 + now, not too
shabby.90+ % edo period, Soga school, Kano school, Tosa school, I
love them.

Milt

Sujikabuto@...

Matt

>
>
> Dear Friends,
>
> I've been in Chicago on personal business since late Thursday. Heading
> back home today, but in no hurry to drive out, so I have a free day. Is

> be worth visiting today? I'm completely ignorant of what Chicago has to
> offer in this sense. I'll check email within the next couple of hours
> (it is 7:30 CT as I write this) for any responses.
>
> Domo arigato!!!
>
> Best Regards,
